vectorData.altText: Each vertebral body is joined to the next by an intervertebral disc which consists of an outer, tough, fibrocartilaginous annulus fibrosus    , and a gelatinous core called the nucleus pulposus     . The intervertebral disc offers tough, flexible support. The annulus fibrosus anchors the intervertebral disc to the vertebral body. The highly hydrated nucleus pulposis withstands compression and is very deformable, thereby allowing the discs to act as a shock absorbers between vertebrae and permitting flexion     , extension     and rotation     of the vertebral column.
decreases the angle between articulating elements; you flex your vertebral column when you bend forward
increases the angle between articulating elements; you extend your vertebral column when you stand up straight
occurs around the long axis of a body part; you rotate your vertebral column when you turn to the right and the left

nucleus pulposus pushes through the annulus fibrosis into the intervertebral foramen, thus compressing a spinal nerve or its root.
